content: today I'm going to be jumping back into a modern setting and I'm gonna be
banging out what is arguably one of the most iconic bits of scatter terrain for
a modern setting
[Applause] hey guys welcome back to black magic
crafts I'm gonna be building some more post-apocalyptic modern scatter bit here
because I need more things to build up my collection for kill team this is a
game that I've been interested in and I've only played a couple times haven't
even finished painting Mike though team but I want to play more and I need more
things to decorate my table with because the vast majority of my collection is
fantasy based one really quick way to fill up any modern or post epochal is
with shipping containers this is a classic bit of terrain they can be used
in all sorts of ways to break up line of sight stack and whatever they're just a
really iconic classic project that I've never built before so today I'm gonna
make a couple I'm gonna be making them out of dollar-store foam core this is
the good stuff not the easy peel stuff I don't want easy peel I want well bonded
paper first thing I got to do is cut a bunch of cubes well rectangle cubes and
then I can start decorating them to make them look like shipping containers I'm
gonna make these two and a half inches by two and a half inches by five inches
because my research tells me and by research I mean check you know what Mel
the Train tutor did when he built his that's a good measurement so that's what
I'm gonna use I have to figure out a little bit what size I need to cut each
piece to accommodate four thickness of foam in the way they overlap but my
final cubes gonna be that size so let's start some monotonous repetitive cutting
and gluing
[Applause]
[Applause]
I think six is enough to kind of fill up an average-size kill team table along
with some other terrain the scrap piece of foam I had was enough to make four of
these little five-inch guys but I wanted some longer ones that I could have for
some variation and to be able to more quickly fill up the space so I made two
that were twice as long use ones are ten inches long but still two and a half by
two and a half of the other direction now I've got to actually decorate these
things to look like shipping containers and shipping containers tend to have
like a corrugated metal on the sides and the top and then the doors are a
different style often that are more flat and maybe have a couple ridges for the
sides on the top I'm gonna use this corrugated paper this stuff is
absolutely awesome it's ready to use perfect corrugation I got this on Amazon
I'll put a link in the description below if you want to grab some you can get
away with making this yourself by peeling cardboard that's the right size
but that's a huge hassle why not just use the stuff that's ready to go so I'm
gonna put this on the two sides and the top I'm just going to leave the bottoms
flat and plain so that they stack and I say there's no reason to do anything
there and then for the ends I'm gonna use some cereal box food packaging to
make up the doors
[Applause]
all right these things are all cheated up and I know what some of you were
thinking did he just use a glue stick damn fools gone crazy
you can't use a glue stick on crap this week can't use this attaching paper to
paper you got a couple options one you don't want to use hot glue it's just too
thick and you know you just don't want hot glue to attach paper to paper you
can of course use PVA that takes a while to dry so that leaves you with tacky
glue which is just thicker PVA and it's thick it's a little bit tricky to work
with you got to brush it all on and I had a lot to do so a glue stick is
actually a fantastic option for this not any glue stick i buy these Elmer's
extreme and these things are actually very very good it's basically tacky glue
in stick form now I wouldn't necessarily trust this for things like foam to foam
or anything really important that's gonna be under a lot of stress but paper
to paper you get a good coating of this it's gonna be plenty strong I've used it
lots of times to do kind of corrugation cladding sort of stuff on small items
I've never used it for anything is big so I'm hoping I don't regret my decision
but I'm feeling pretty confident in it before I actually do the different
strips that I want to do for the door I'm just thinking about the order in
which the different corrugations meet up on these things and I'm realizing that I
want to add the strip's all around the rest of it first and then do the doors
last so now I am gonna take some of this thinner cereal box style cardboard this
is from waffles read a lot of waffles in my house and I'm gonna cut a bunch of
narrow strips to clad all of the corners and I cut a test piece that was visually
the size that I wanted I'm not using a scale here I just what what looks right
that looks right then figure out what the size is 3/16 of an inch which is
kind of an awkward increment to layout I want to lay out a ton of these and make
them exactly the same certainly can do it with that but that is an awkward
fractal measurement to lay out a whole bunch of intervals
three sixteenths of an inch is basically exactly the same as five millimeters so
I'm going to switch over to metric to lay this out just because it's a number
that works well in metric speaking of measurements I can't a lot of people who
complain about them I'm Canadian so I use metric and imperial we are
technically a metric country but in reality we use imperial for most
building things and as a carpenter who worked professionally in construction I
worked in imperial 99% of the time I think an imperial it is I don't care
what you say it is a better measurement for construction of things like houses
even in metric countries they often switch to imperial standards for wood
framing because it makes sense they're just numbers a lot of us know how to use
both and you should too because then you get in a situation like this where you
can just switch to a different method that works better for the purpose so for
this I'm switching to metric so let's cut a bunch of five millimeter strips
and attach them to these shipping containers
now while doing this I tried a few
different glues I tried the glue stick first it was a failure there's just not
enough surface area on this corrugated paper for it to bond to I also tried
superglue but that was a royal pain and I gave up on that immediately so I
switched to tacky glue just brushing it on and going that way a little bit messy
to do but it worked really well now for the door itself I'm going off of a
reference photo here and I'm gonna try to make them look like they have these
bigger panels that are running horizontally but first I need to put two
vertical strips of this cladding in to kind of differentiate between the two
panels of the door I want this to be right to this edge of Center and I'm
just eyeballing this you can measure it out and that's not honestly not a bad
idea when doing a lot of like fantasy type builds a little bit of variation
can look just fine you know in the stonework and whatnot but when doing
modern stuff you actually do you want a little bit more precision especially
when making something like this that would be manufactured so it's not a bad
idea to spend some extra time marking things out and measuring them if you're
not comfortable eyeballing it with enough accuracy but you know me that's
not how I roll I left a small gap in between them now
for the horizontal strips I cut some bigger pieces that are 3/8 of an inch so
quite a bit wider than these five millimeter strips here oh don't you just
love the mix of Imperial and metric I can hear every German screaming I found
the best way to do this is to just dab on a little bit of glue onto my piece
place my strip and then cut off the excess and because I'm not measuring
this out but I want them to be equally spaced I'm doing the top in the bottom
one first that way if there's any discrepancy in my spacing it can be in
the center space and it won't actually look that weird looking at my reference
photo these shipping containers always seem to have these little square corner
pieces with holes in and it would look really nice to add
that to these cut a whole bunch of little squares add an extra square piece
maybe drill a hole in it but they have them on every corner so for one
container that's four eight twelve sixteen twenty squares per container and
I got six of these so that's already like 100 and 120 of these squares that
have to cut and glue on and after spending a good couple hours doing this
I'm not in the mood so I'm gonna skip that one thing I do need though are
these pins these containers always have these pins for locking the door these
kind of rods I need something for that the best thing would be small styrene
rods but I don't keep styrene rods I don't have any there's nowhere even
remotely close to me that sells them the only place in the city I can think of
that would have them there's like a 45-minute drive away barbecue skewers
will be too big toothpicks won't look right
I need something this might be a super clever solution spaghetti looks perfect
but I'm not sure how well I can cut this without it exploding pretty good this is
definitely a job for super glue people always ask what is this stuff that I
spray in my videos well tell you that's why I have an essential equipment page
where I list all the stuff I use this is accelerant and it's something that
everybody using superglue should own it'll make your life way easier on my
page find a link there that worked awesome the spaghetti is obviously a
very fragile thing I wouldn't trust it on most terrain but it's almost entirely
supported by the peeps here it's only in the grooves where it's not and I think
that's gonna be fine well I gotta say I'm pretty pleased
with this you know what they say about necessity and mothers gotta add these to
all of these crates maybe I will cut some squares here if I just put squares
on the end we'll see
well that worked out awesomely who would have thought that spaghetti would save
the day on high terrain build I decided not to go and put all the hundred and
twenty little squares or even a reduced number of them on these I want to get my
Mod Podge on this so that it's ready for paint tomorrow and I have pretty much
run out of time for the day to get to this point it's been over seven hours of
work to do this so I just got to wrap it up and I got to cook my family supper
probably spaghetti so Mod Podge then dinner tomorrow I'll paint these bad
boys out it's officially day two on this project I ended up staying up pretty
late last night getting these primed and ready for paint I spray painted them
with a black primer and I was actually spray priming in the dark in the middle
of the night so that was fun I am at a crossroads I'm at a pivotal decision
point on these I want them to look pretty old and beaten up so I'm gonna
want them to be painted but I'm gonna want a lot of paint chips and rust on
them and there's two approaches I could take to doing this one method is to
paint them out whatever the paint color is gonna be and then using a sponge to
stipple on the paint chips and the rust effects this is a pretty tricky way to
do it it requires a fair amount of skill and a good artistic eye the other
approach I could take is painting them all out in a rust color and then doing
the hairspray or similar coating and then a coat of the paint and then using
a wet brush start actually chipping away the top layer paint to reveal the rust
beneath it and I've only done this once before it's a fairly easy way to go
because you literally are chipping away the paint so it has a pretty realistic
look but there's some definite challenges to doing this method the
timing is really important if you spray too many of them at once and wait too
long to start chipping the paint away it doesn't come off very easily and you
end up removing the rust layer beneath it and it just doesn't kind of work out
the timing is difficult so I want to cut out a stencil and then paint on some
lettering I'm concerned that it's just gonna not work out what I try to chip
them all so I have to do a whole bunch of these to the timing is really tricky
I hidden thinking I'm gonna attempt that method anyway and if it doesn't work out
I will realize quickly and then I can just pivot and go on to the stippling
technique yeah hopefully that works let's get these paint at a rusty Brown
and hope for the best
I really don't know if this is gonna
work I've never done a airbrush stencil before and this is a pretty tricky place
to start with this corrugated texture on this thing there's gonna be some bleed
there's a few ways you could counteract that by sealing the edges or using spray
adhesive with the hairspray thing going on feel like that might cause me some
problems you gonna try to blow this as straight on as possible not at an angle
because I don't want to get behind the stencil if I can avoid it
stencils moving a lot you tried reducing my pressure on the airbrush all right
moment of truth this could look awful and not very good I suppose it could be
worse but it could certainly be a lot better
let's just say I'm really thankful that
these particular objects are really forgiving in terms of their paint jobs
because the last couple hours did not go well for me after my first failed
stencil attempt I tried the paint chipping and that actually works really
well the test one was a success and I was happy with it and I felt comfortable
proceeding to doing the rest I realized that I had a ton of airbrushing to do
and even after doing the brown kind of rust painting in here it was just too
much to be doing in this space I wear a mask so I'm not breathing in all the
particulates from the paint but all that little dust from the airbrush kind of
goes in the air and eventually settles on stuff and because I'm not painting in
kind of like a dirty shop this is a nice finished space where all my finished
projects are on my gaming stuff I didn't want all that dust settling on
everything I don't have a little spray booth I will build one eventually that I
need to do that really soon I don't have one and I decided I should just set up
shop outside bit of a pain in the butt but I took my compressor airbrush all my
stuff some paint outside set up on my kids little craft table and went to town
we got new neighbors that just moved in last week and if they happen to look up
to I don't see what I was doing they're probably very confused about who they
moved in next to like what is this weird tattooed guy spray-painting little boxes
on a time anyway I felt like taking a bit of a risk and painting
the base coat color on all of these just hoping that the paint chipping would
work after leaving them for a while and in retrospect that was actually an okay
decision because it did work on all them but my airbrushing I don't know I was
just in a hurry not taking my time and I kind of made every mistake that you can
make when airbrushing I over thinned my paint and had to much thinner and was
spraying too much of it on and the thing is when you spray on too much wet thin
paint onto the hairspray it kind of rehydrates makes a big mess it was not
good I didn't take the time to mix things properly and spray lightly it was
just a bit of a disaster in my frustration after completing all the
base colors I decided to clean the airbrush because I had been kind of
abusing it ever since getting my owada airbrush it's been nothing but a dream
to work with it's never really clogged on me I've taken it apart multiple times
it's been an absolute pleasure to work with
I fully disassembled it and took it apart and to clean it out because I was
just rushing and just not in a good space when I was putting on the little
spray tip which is a tiny tiny tiny little threaded piece I reef Don it like
an idiot and I broke the tip which is now the second time I've done that on an
airbrush this time 100% absolutely my fault I was just being dumb I couldn't
continue on doing the stenciling with an airbrush because I didn't have one that
was functioning what if I just used aerosol spray paint just like some white
spray primer and this actually might be easier to dust lightly and not bleed
through the stencil when I went to do the paint chipping turns out and I kind
of knew this in the back of my head but I was hoping it wouldn't be true turns
out the rehydration method of water and chipping the paint doesn't work when
there's a coating of a non water-based paint on it so doing the chipping on the
scenting was very very difficult luckily I tested that after only doing one but
that is why there's no other stenciling on these pieces which is a bit of a
shame because I think that's one of the things that really
makes shipping containers look awesome but overall I was not having very good
luck with the stencil my airbrush is broken just kind of a disaster so I'm
just gonna leave these as is All Things Considered they still look pretty darn
good and I'm just gonna continue on and get this project wrapped up the first
thing I need to do to make these look right is paint out these metal bars and
handles I don't think they look right just blending in I'm gonna paint them
out with a metallic and then I'm gonna go through with a little bit of washes
and maybe some rust effects but I'm not gonna go overboard because these
actually look pretty decent as is well I say that but I probably will end up
going overboard and just drenching them
all right I am calling this project officially complete did they turn out
perfect absolutely not but they turned out good enough and quite frankly these
are gonna look just fine on my table for a game of kill team or whatever there
was a lot of challenges during this project and I hope you enjoyed seeing
them you know it'd be really easy for me to just build all these fumble through
it record a perfect version of it for a
tutorial I'm just not interested in doing that sort of thing anymore I think
there's a lot more value in showing the real struggles of a crafter I know it
can be super discouraging if you see makers on YouTube build things and it
just goes perfectly and then you try it for yourself you break something you
spill something make a mess something doesn't work it looks bad and you can be
really discouraging when you think that oh man you must suck and all these other
people do it perfectly but the reality is nobody does it perfectly it's always
a struggle and there's always problems so I've been really enjoying sharing
those with you I've been enjoying this kind of new format of more storytelling
vlog versus perfect a tutorial so I hope you enjoy that as well if you did enjoy
this video please hit the like button and let me know in the comment section
below that stuff really helps the videos gain traction on the platform if you
want to pick up any tools or supplies to do the stuff for yourself check out my
essential equipment page on black magic craft dot CA I have links to most of the
stuff that I use regularly that way you get the exact thing that you need
they'll be little descriptors as to what everything is and why I use it
purchasing through those links actually helps fund the production of videos like
this because they are Amazon affiliate links and every time you purchase
something after clicking on one of those I get a commission and that goes into
making these videos if you really like what I do you get a lot of value out of
these videos I highly encourage you to consider supporting black magic crafts
on patreon that support is crucial to allowing me to spend so much time doing
this because it does take a lot of time if you join up there's some cool rewards
like a private Facebook group and a private discord server where I am fairly
active and it's full of other great awesome crafters who are there to help
you on your crafting journey so think about it it would mean a lot to me
if you did that's it for this week guys Cheers
I will see you again next week
